description:
The AbsorptionSpectrum analysis module has the ability to add lines as well as continuua sources (like lyman continuum absorption at 912 A), but there were a couple of bugs preventing it from working in all cases.  This PR addresses those bugs, adds test coverage, updates the documentation, and includes a lot of comments for what is happening in the code.  In addition, there is a bunch of code that got reformatted because it went beyond the 80 char limit.

The two bugs that were addressed are as follows:

1) the column_density values are calculated by multiplying densities in cgs by path lengths in kpc, which left it in units of `cm**-3*kpc`.  When these values were multiplied by some non-unitful input values, it resulted in wrong values, so I recast these as `cm**-2`, the traditional units of column densities in astro.  

2) previously, we apply a cutoff in column density for absorbers in terms of whether or not we calculate their effects on continuum sources.  this cutoff threshold is equal to `min_tau * normalization`, where the `min_tau` is the minimum optical depth we care about (i.e. 1e-3) and `normalization` is the user-provided column density that should elicit an optical depth of 1 at the defined wavelength.  but the problem is that we get different behavior from a single absorber with X column density > cutoff than if we have N absorbers each with X/N column density < cutoff even though the total column density for both cases = X.  

This is corrected by scaling our `min_tau` value by the number of absorbers present to assure collections of seemingly inconsequential absorbers don't get ignored en masse when their effects add up to a consequential continuum.

I have gone through the math and done a lot of tests to assure this behavior works, which is why I'm commenting this so heavily.  Any feedback is welcome.

UPDATE1: Fixing test failure.

UPDATE2: Merging with @ngoldbaum 's GenericArrayTest fix.

UPDATE3: Fixing issues pointed out by @brittonsmith .
